title: The face as an attentional signal: Electrophysiological correlates of attentional capture and interactions with working
abstractText: Humans are social animals, and as social animals, faces are very important perceptual objects often conveying information that may be important for survival. In this project we will examine whether, due to their social importance, faces are ‘special cues’ for visual attention. We will examine whether our attention is drawn automatically to a face as opposed to other types of stimuli (non-human faces, other types of object), when we view a scene. We will also examine whether any effects are modulated by memory – for example, when we carry in mind a particular face that we are looking for. The experiments will use behavioural measures (reaction times, errors) plus also visual-evoked responses (reflecting momentary changes in scalp activity) to provide an ‘on-line’ measure of attentional capture.
